ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Characterization of nanostructured CuO–porous silicon matrix formed on copper-coated silicon substrate via electrochemical etching

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: A pulsed anodic etching method has been utilized for nanostructuring of a copper-coated p-type (100) silicon substrate, using HF-based solution as electrolyte. Scanning electron microscopy reveals the formation of a nanostructured matrix that consists of island-like textures with nanosize grains grown onto fiber-like columnar structures separated with etch pits of grooved porous structures. Spatial micro-Raman scattering analysis indicates that the island-like texture is composed of single-phase cupric oxide (CuO) nanocrystals, while the grooved porous structure is barely related to formation of porous silicon (PS). X-ray diffraction shows that both the grown CuO nanostructures and the etched silicon layer have the same preferred (220) orientation. Chemical composition obtained by means of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) analysis confirms the presence of the single-phase CuO on the surface of the patterned CuO–PS matrix. As compared to PS formed on the bare silicon substrate, the room-temperature photoluminescence (PL) from the CuO–PS matrix exhibits an additional weak ‘blue’ PL band as well as a blue shift in the PL band of PS (S-band). This has been revealed from XPS analysis to be associated with the enhancement in the SiO2 content as well as formation of the carbonyl group on the surface in the case of the CuO–PS matrix.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: In the last two decades, nanostructuring of semiconductors has gained more and more steadfast attention of researchers as an alternative way for engineering their properties on demand. The most popular example is porous silicon (PS), which has attracted much attention after the discovery of its luminescence properties in 1990 [1]. Due to the reduced size of silicon nanocrystals and voids, in the range of a few nanometers, PS is a quasi-continuous optical medium for the visible and infrared spectral ranges. Apart from the light-emitting properties, PS has other very interesting characteristics, including the possibility of modulating the refractive index in a simple way during formation, the large surface area to volume ratio (>500 cm−1) and the non-toxicity of PS layers. These make PS a very attractive candidate for potential applications in biological and chemical sensing, mass spectrometry, new material supports, biocompatible materials, vivoelectronics and solar cells. Many of these PS applications have been researched [2–7].

Recently, nanostructures of metal/metal oxide–PS have attracted an extensive attention due to their very attractive modified properties of great importance in many fields of science and technology [8–15]. For example, the electroluminescence efficiency from PS has been found to highly increase after deposition of indium and aluminum into its pores [8]. Ambient full-color PL from PS is obtained through electrochemical etching aided by Zn as oxidative metal without any post-anodizing treatment [9]. Singh et al. have reported white-light emission across an extended visible region of the electromagnetic spectrum from the ZnO–PS nanocomposite [11]. Ozdemir and Gole have investigated the effect of different nanostructured oxidized metal nanoparticle depositions on PS gas sensors [14]. They observed significant improvements in the sensor response for phosphine detection when naked PS is coated with Au x O and Cu x O nanostructures. More recently, it has been shown that the growth of WO3 nanorods onto PS leads to an improvement of NO2 sensing properties of PS [15].

As a p-type semiconductor with a narrow band gap of E g=1.2 eV [16], cupric oxide (CuO) has a great potential for different technological applications such as solar cells [17], magnetic storage media [18], gas sensors [19], field emission [20] and heterogeneous catalysis [21]. CuO-based materials are also well known with regard to their giant magnetoresistance and high-temperature superconductivity [22]. In the past three decades, great efforts have been devoted for synthesizing of CuO nanostructures. Nanostructured CuO materials may exhibit unique properties that can be significantly different from those of their bulk counterparts, such as unusual optical, electric and catalytic properties [23]. Moreover, copper oxide–PS nanostructures are of importance for many potential applications, such as photo-electrochemical cells [24] and biological and gas sensing [14, 25]. For example, it has been found that coating an n-type silicon photo-electrode with a copper oxide thin film leads to an enhancement in its photo-electrochemical conversion efficiency [24].

As in the case of ZnO–PS, various methods and techniques can be utilized for formation of PS–copper oxide nanostructures, including electroplating processes [8], metal-assisted electrochemical/chemical etching [9, 12], vapor–liquid–solid (VLS) processes [10], chemical routes of sol–gel spin coating [11], electrochemical deposition [14] and thermal evaporation [15].

In the present report, an electrochemical etching method is utilized for nanostructuring of a p-type (100) silicon substrate coated with a thin copper film (Cu–Si). The produced nanostructured cupric oxide–porous silicon (CuO–PS) matrix has been characterized by means of scanning electron microscopy (SEM), micro-Raman scattering, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and room-temperature photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy.

Section2.Heading: Formation process
Section2.Para: One-side-mirror-polished 〈100〉-oriented p-type boron-doped silicon wafers with resistivity of 1–20 Ω cm were coated with Cu thin films (70 nm) by vacuum arc deposition using a V-1000 ‘U’ system from a pure copper target. The coated samples were anodized in an electrolytic solution of 44 % HF and 99.99 % ethanol in a proportion of 1:1. The electrochemical etching cell was designed in single-tank geometry [26]. It consisted of two cylindrical Teflon sections, with a cavity in the upper section for electrolyte injection. A platinum electrode was immersed in the electrolyte solution and an aluminum plate served as two electrodes of the cell. A pulsed power supply with output voltage operating in a constant-voltage mode similar to one described elsewhere [27] was used for the etching process. Under darkness, a 10 min etching process was carried out by applying a pulsed current between the two electrodes at peak current density of 12 mA/cm2 with pulse duration of 10 ms. After etching, the sample were rinsed with de-ionized water, dried in an N2 stream and the naked-eye red luminescence under excitation with a UV lamp was observed from the formed layer.

Section2.Heading: Characterization techniques
Section2.Para: The PL spectra were recorded at room temperature using a 1 m monochromator (SPEX) equipped a multialkali photomultiplier and a liquid nitrogen cooled InGaAs detector. The PL spectra were excited by a 325 nm (∼3.82 eV) HeCd laser. A TESCAN VIGA II XMU scanning electron microscope (SEM) was used to investigate surface topography of the samples. The Raman spectra excited by a 20 mW argon laser at wavelength 488 nm were measured in 180∘ back-scattering configuration at room temperature using a micro-Raman system (HR 800, Jobin Yvon Horiba). The crystallographic properties of the prepared matrix were studied by using a STOE powder diffractometer operated in reflection mode. The XPS spectra were recorded using a SPECS UHV/XPS/AES system with a hemispherical energy analyzer. A monochromated Al Ka X-ray source (1486.6 eV) is used for excitation and is operated at 250 W. High-resolution spectra of the XPS peaks are treated and deconvoluted, with CasaXPS version 2.3.16Dev52, using a nonlinear least-squares method with a Gaussian/Lorentzian peak shape GL(30) and the background was subtracted using the Shirley method [28]. All XPS binding energies were referenced to the C 1s peak at a binding energy of 285 eV to compensate for surface charging effects. The total acquisition time of our XPS spectra was about 60 min.

Section2.Heading: Surface topography
Section2.Para:
Figure 1 shows SEM micrographs of the etched Cu–Si sample at three different magnifications. At low magnification, the topography of the surface is seen to be consisting of island-like textures grown and distributed onto nanosized fiber-like columnar structures (region B), which are separated with etch pits (region A). As will be demonstrated in the next subsections, the regions A and B are composed of CuO nanostructures and PS, respectively. Therefore, the observed bunching behavior of fibrous structures can be attributed to the significant difference in the surface energy between these two regions. In particular, the difference in the hydrophobicity and the porosity at the interface between the two regions more strongly affects the lower side of the fibrous structures. Hence, the fibers tend to incline and agglutinate together. A similar phenomenon has been observed for CuO nanowires synthesized within a porous anodic aluminum oxide template by a citrate-based sol–gel route [29].
Fig. 1
SEM micrographs of the etched Cu–Si sample at three different magnifications

At higher magnification imaging, the nanostructuring aspects of both regions are clearly revealed. The region B exhibits an agglomeration of micro/nanosized grains, while the region A shows a grooved nanoporous structure. The width of grooves in the region A is measured from the SEM image to be less than 100 nm, whereas the grain size in the region B is found to be in the range of ∼40–170 nm.

Section2.Heading: Micro-Raman scattering
Section2.Para:
SEM investigations are augmented by micro-Raman spectroscopy, which allows investigation with micron spatial resolution. Under the optical microscope of the micro-Raman spectroscope system, the micro-Raman spectra of the patterned layer have been recorded by focusing the light of the exciting laser onto either the region A or the region B. Figure 2 shows the micro-Raman spectra for the bare crystalline silicon (c-Si) substrate and region A and region B of the etched Cu–Si sample. The spectrum of the c-Si substrate shows a strong and sharp longitudinal optical (LO) one-phonon Raman band centered at ∼520.6 cm−1, with full width at half maximum (FWHM) of ∼2.7 cm−1, and a very weak phonon frequency at ∼303 cm−1, due to the surface-assisted 2TA (transverse acoustic) mode [30]. In comparison, the Raman spectrum of the region A shows several new Raman features. The main one-phonon band in the spectrum of this region shows clear asymmetry and exhibits a high-frequency tail extending up to around 420 cm−1. A method of least square with a Gaussian line shape is used to deconvolute this band into three peaks, as shown in Fig. 3. The sharpest peak at ∼520.6 cm−1, with FWHM of ∼2.8 cm−1, corresponds to the LO mode of the c-Si substrate. The broad peak at ∼519 cm−1, with FWHM of ∼8.9 cm−1, is associated with nanocrystalline silicon [31]. The broadest peak at ∼492 cm−1, with FWHM of ∼35 cm−1, is related to a network of hydrogenated amorphous (disordered) silicon [32]. The observed crystallite size distribution and disorder features in the Raman spectra of this region have been observed in the Raman spectra of PS [33]. This gives rigid evidence of PS formation in region A. However, the intensity of the LO peak in this region decreases by about one order of magnitude with respect to that of the silicon substrate. It has been reported that the intensity of the disorder modes dramatically affects the crystalline Si peak [34]. As the intensity of the disorder modes increases, the crystalline Si peak decreases. On the other hand, it is reported that the reduction in Si crystallite size in the silicon network leads to significant enhancement in the one-phonon Raman line [35]. However, it is found from the fitting results of Fig. 3 that the ratios of the integrated areas for the disordered to crystalline peaks and for the nanocrystalline to crystalline peaks are around 0.82 and 0.54, respectively. This high level of disorder may explain the observed reduction in the intensity of the LO peak for the PS sample with respect to that of the c-Si substrate. In addition, the relative intensity ratio of the 2TA mode to the LO mode is enhanced from ∼0.048 for the silicon substrate to ∼0.3 for PS (region A). This also can be attributed to the disorder enhancement in the case of PS [36].
Fig. 2
Micro-Raman spectra for: the bare silicon substrate and the etched Cu–Si sample that were recorded by focusing the light of the exciting laser onto either the region (A) or the region (B) of the produced matrix
Fig. 3
One-phonon Raman spectra for the electrochemically etched Cu–Si sample. Solid line represents the spectrum as it is recorded and dashed one after the deconvolution

On the other hand, the Raman spectrum of region B does not exhibit any peak due to silicon modes. Instead, it exhibits typical Raman features of CuO nanocrystals. Three main broad bands centered at 273, 321 and 613 cm−1 are observed in the spectrum of this region. These peaks correspond to Ag, Bg(1) and Bg(2) modes of bulk CuO crystals [37], respectively. However, the observed red shift in the position of this line in comparison with the reported results for crystalline CuO indicates the formation of nanostructure phases of CuO in this region [38–40]. In addition, the Raman spectrum of this region does not show any explicit bands related to Cu2O [41], demonstrating the single-phase property of the formed CuO nanocrystals. Hence, the correlation of Raman results to SEM observation reveals that the observed island-like textures of region B are composed of CuO nanocrystals, and that the grooved porous structures of region A are due to formation of PS.

Section2.Heading: XRD analysis
Section2.Para:
Figure 4 shows XRD patterns of the CuO–PS matrix, which exhibits several diffraction peaks. The diffraction peaks at around 2θ=43.2∘, 50.3∘ and 74.1∘ correspond to (111), (200) and (220) crystallographic planes of cubic Cu, respectively (PDF card no. 65-3288). The diffraction peaks at around 2θ=25.7∘ and 47.7∘ correspond to crystallographic planes of cubic Si, respectively. The most important in the XRD patterns is the strong peak at around 2θ=68.1∘, which consists of (220) crystallographic planes of monoclinic CuO phase (PDF card no. 48-1548). Interestingly, both the growth direction of the nanostructured CuO and the underlying etched Si substrate have the same preferred (220) orientation. It has been found that the preferred orientation of a copper oxide nanostructure is strongly influenced by the used substrate and the synthesis methods and parameters [42, 43]. For example, Mei et al. have investigated the growth of Cu oxide nanowire arrays on Si-based SiO2 nanoscale islands via nanochannels of a Si-based porous anodic alumina template at room temperature under a pulsed voltage in a conventional solution for copper electrodeposition [43]. They found that the preferential growth direction of Cu oxide nanowires is connected with the nanoscale SiO2 islands. Moreover, no diffraction peaks due to Cu2O phase could be detected in XRD patterns of the formed matrix, which is consistent with Raman results.
Fig. 4
XRD pattern of CuO–PS matrix formed on the electrochemically etched Cu–Si sample

Section2.Heading: XPS surface analysis
Section2.Para:
The chemical composition of the produced matrix is further investigated using XPS spectroscopy. The XPS survey scan of the etched Cu–Si surface exhibited the expected series of photoemission and Auger peaks arising from Si, Cu, C and O. Figure 5 shows the high-resolution XPS peaks for (a) Cu 2p, (b) Si 2p and (c) C 1s of the etched Cu–Si surface. The spectrum of Cu 2p exhibits two strong peaks corresponding to Cu 2p1/2 and Cu 2p3/2 core levels at around 952 eV and 932.4 eV, respectively. The peak deconvolution of the Cu 2p3/2 level reveals two binding energy components centered at 931.8 eV and 933.7 eV. The lower binding energy component has FWHM of around 1.9 eV, and it is assigned to Cu2O [44]. The higher binding energy component, with FWHM of around 3.1 eV, is assigned to CuO [45]. The percentage concentration ratio of CuO/Cu2O is found to be around 1.1. The XPS results show a strong presence of Cu2O on the Cu–Si etched surface, which seems to be in contradiction with micro-Raman and XRD results. However, it is well established that X-ray exposure during acquisition of XPS spectra induces reduction of Cu2+ (CuO) to Cu1+ (Cu2O). The reduction of CuO to Cu2O during XPS analysis has been thoroughly studied in the literature and has been attributed to the integrated X-ray dose [46], heating from the X-ray gun [47], outgassing in a vacuum [48] and slow electrons emanating from the X-ray window during analysis [49]. In addition, the observed shake-up features at ∼943 and ∼962 eV for the Cu 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 core levels are evident and diagnostic of an open 3d9 shell of Cu(+2). The peak positions of the shake-up satellites from these levels are indicative of the presence of CuO at the surface [47–50]. The two satellite peaks have yet to be identified but they are possibly due to non-stoichiometric cupric oxide (Cu1−δ O) [40].
Fig. 5
High-resolution XPS spectra for (a) Cu 2p, (b) Si 2p and (c) C 1s of the etched Cu–Si surface. Solid line for each peak represents the spectrum as it is recorded and the dotted one is after deconvolution

The deconvolution of the high-resolution spectrum of the Si 2p core level peak gives two components centered at binding energies of ∼99.3 and ∼103.5 eV, which are assigned to Si–Si bonds and silicon oxide SiO2, respectively [51, 52]. The percentage concentration of the SiO2 component with respect to that of Si (SiO2/Si) is found to be around 2.7, which indicates that the surface of the PS region on the etched surface (region A) is rather SiO2-rich.

In order to understand the effect of Cu deposition on the chemical composition of the produced PS, the XPS spectra of PS formed on the bare (uncoated) silicon substrate at the same etching conditions were also recorded.

Figure 6 shows the high-resolution XPS spectra of (a) C 1s and (b) Si 2p levels for the PS sample formed on the bare silicon substrate. The deconvolution of the C 1s peak of this sample shows only two components due to alkyl compound (CH x ) and C–C binding centered at around 283.6 and 285.2 eV, respectively. The XPS peak due to the carbonyl group is not revealed in this case. Moreover, the deconvolution of the Si 2p peak of this sample reveals, in addition to a Si–Si bond component at 99.2 eV, two components centered at around 101.3 and 102.8 eV, which are assigned to Si–O bindings in sub-oxides SiO x (x<2) [53, 54]. The disappearance of the SiO2 peak and the enhancement the relative intensity of the Si peak in the spectrum of this sample indicate that the silicon oxide on the surface of this sample is rather silicon-rich. Hence, it can be deduced that the Cu coating of the silicon substrate catalyzes the formation of both SiO2 and carbonyl compound species on the etched surface.
Fig. 6
High-resolution XPS spectra of (a) C 1s and (b) Si 2p levels for PS sample formed on the bare silicon substrate. Solid line for each peak represents the spectrum as it is recorded and the dotted one is after deconvolution

Based on our above experimental results and analysis, a qualitative visualization of the possible mechanism for formation of the CuO–PS matrix is schematically described in Fig. 7. At earlier stages of the etching process, the native Cu2O thin layer is first dissolved and removed from the Cu film surface by the effect of HF in the electrolyte. The surface of the cleaned Cu film interacts with the hydroxyl ions of the etching electrolyte and in turn leads to formation of a new Cu2O layer. The formed Cu2O layer then interacts with HF and selectively dissolves in the electrolyte. The consecutive formation and dissolution of the Cu2O layer on the surface of the Cu film leads to a selective etching of the Cu film and a generation of Cu ions in the electrolyte (Step (1)). On increasing the etching time, a matrix of Cu islands and free Cu regions is formed. However, the electrolyte solution will become saturated with Cu ions after sufficient time of etching and hence the dissolution of the Cu film will be suppressed. At this stage, the oxidation of the formed Cu2O layer on Cu islands as well as the formation of PS on the free Cu regions dominate the formation process (Step (2)). These two processes lead finally to formation of the CuO–PS matrix (Step (3)). In addition, the naked-eye observation at the end of the etching process revealed that the Pt electrode of the etching cell was partially covered with the Cu film. This can be attributed to the deposition of reduced Cu ions on its surface. The reaction formulas corresponding to the suggested formation mechanism of the CuO–PS matrix are described as follows:
Step (1): 1
$$\begin{aligned} &{2\mathrm{Cu} + 2\mathrm{OH}^{-}\to \mathrm{Cu}_{2}\mathrm{O} + \mathrm{H}_{2}\mathrm{O} +2\mathrm{e}} \end{aligned}$$
2
$$\begin{aligned} &{\mathrm{Cu}_{2}\mathrm{O} + 2\mathrm{HF}\to \mathrm{Cu}_{2}\mathrm{F}_{2} + \mathrm{H}_{2}\mathrm{O}} \end{aligned}$$
Step (2): 3
$$\begin{aligned} &{\mathrm{Cu}_{2}\mathrm{F}_{2} \to \mathrm{Cu} + \mathrm{CuF}_{2}} \end{aligned}$$
4
$$\begin{aligned} &{\mathrm{Cu}^{+2} + 3\mathrm{F}^{-} \to \mathrm{CuF}_{3}^{-}} \end{aligned}$$
Step (3): 5
$$\begin{aligned} &{\mathrm{Si} + \mathrm{CuF}_{3}^{-}\to \mathrm{Cu} +\mathrm{SiF}_{6}^{-}} \end{aligned}$$
6
$$\begin{aligned} &{\mathrm{Cu}_{2}\mathrm{O} + 2\mathrm{OH}^{-} \to 2\mathrm{CuO} + \mathrm{H}_{2}\mathrm{O} +2\mathrm{e}} \end{aligned}$$
Fig. 7
Schematic views of the formation process of the CuO–PS matrix by electrochemical etching of Cu–Si sample

A point of note is that the migrations of the generated Cu ions to the PS region catalyze both the oxidation of the produced PS layer [55] and the formation of carbonyl compound species in the matrix surface [54]. However, the quantitative description of the formation process requires in-situ measurements that we hope to carry out in the future.

Section2.Heading: Room-temperature photoluminescence
Section2.Para:
The optical properties of the produced CuO–PS matrix are investigated using room-temperature PL measurements and compared to those of PS formed on the bare silicon substrate at the same etching conditions. The PL spectra for both cases are depicted in Fig. 8. The PL spectrum of the PS formed onto the bare silicon sample exhibits a strong ‘red’ PL band centered at around 701 nm, which is the characteristic visible band (S-band) of PS [56]. Despite the discrepancy and the uncertainty about the exact origin of this band in the literature, this band is mostly believed to be the band-to-band transition of the silicon nanocrystals [1]. Compared to the PS of the bare silicon substrate, the peak of this band is blue shifted by about 72 nm and its intensity is slightly decreased in the PL spectrum of the CuO–PS matrix. Both the blue shift and the decrease in the intensity of the S-band PL peak in PS can be induced by enhancing its surface oxidization degree [57]. As is shown from XPS results, the observed behavior of this PL band can be correlated to the increase in the oxidation degree of PS formed in the CuO–PS matrix as compared to PS formed on the bare silicon substrate.
Fig. 8
Room-temperature PL spectra for (i) CuO–PS matrix and (ii) PS sample formed on the bare silicon substrate

Moreover, the PL spectrum of the CuO–PS matrix shows an additional low-intensity ‘blue’ PL band with maximum at around 440 nm. It has been reported that the blue emission from in situ Cu-doped PS is associated with formation of the carbonyl compounds that are catalyzed by Cu on the surface of the PS [54]. However, the blue emission in that case was associated with complete quenching of the PL peak due to the S-band. The quenching in the S-band was attributed to the deposition of Cu ions onto the surface during the etching process. Interestingly, in our case the intensity of the ‘red’ PL band does not show considerable quenching with respect to that of PS formed on the bare silicon substrate. This might exclude the deposition of Cu ions onto the surface of the PS region A during the etching process, which is also in good agreement with our Raman results. Furthermore, it has been reported that blue luminescence from PS originates from SiO2 layers [58]. Therefore, the correlation between our above XPS results and PL spectra of both samples supports the strong relationship between the observed ‘blue’ band and the formation of both carbonyl compounds and SiO2 on the surface. However, the exact origin of this band is not clear since blue PL emission has also been observed for CuO nanostructures [59].

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: Simple formation of a nanostructured CuO–PS matrix by electrochemical etching of a Cu-coated silicon substrate is demonstrated. Characterization via SEM, spatial micro-Raman scattering, XRD and XPS confirm that the formed matrix consisted of island-like CuO nanostructures separated with SiO2-rich PS regions. XPS results also revealed the formation of carbonyl compound species on the surface of the CuO–PS matrix. These are found to result in an improvement in the visible PL emission from the CuO–PS matrix. As compared to PS formed on a bare silicon substrate, the room-temperature PL due to PS of the CuO–PS matrix exhibits a blue shift in the PL peak of the S-band as well as an additional weak ‘blue’ PL band. The synthesized nanostructured CuO–PS matrix has attraction for biological/chemical sensing that is foreseen in the future.

Acknowledgments.Heading: Acknowledgement
Acknowledgments.SimplePara: The authors would like to thank the Director General of AECS, Prof. I. Othman, for encouragement and support.
